'M and M' freshmen lead Louisville women to W's

Myisha Hines-Allen and Mariya Moore are Cardinals' top two scorers

'M and M' freshmen lead Louisville women to W's

Steve Jones, swjones1@courier-journal.com 9:47 p.m. EST December 3, 2014

Louisville's Mariya Moore drives to the basket against UT Martin; the freshman is averaging 14.3 points a game.(Photo: David Lee Hartlage, Special to the C-J)

1 CONNECT 1 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

It seems reasonable that there would be a nickname at this point for the University of Louisville freshman duo of Myisha Hines-Allen and Mariya Moore, whose seemingly seamless transitions to the college game have helped the Cardinals to a 7-0 start.

"What, like a 'Batman and Robin' type thing?" Hines-Allen asked backed to a reporter. "No."

So lacking a label for Myisha and Mariya, Hines-Allen laughed and suggested a good, simple one on the fly: "'M and M,' that's what we call each other. Or, we'll start."

Whether the nickname takes hold, "M and M" have been a treat for the Cards early on.

With big challenges upcoming against No. 22 Iowa (6-1) Thursday night and No. 13 Kentucky on Sunday, Hines-Allen and Moore have been leading the Cards' offense.

MORE: Moore sharp as Cardinals top Ball State

MORE: Freshman tandem gives No. 12 Cardinals big lift

Hines-Allen, a 6-foot-2 power forward from New Jersey, is U of L's top scorer at 15.1 points per game and the Cards' first-ever ACC Freshman of the Week. Moore, a 6-0 wing from California, is right behind her and second on the team at 14.3 ppg.

"We recruited them to come in as freshmen and contribute," coach Jeff Walz said. "That's kind of what we anticipated, and they've done exactly what we'd planned on them doing. We knew both of them could score."

Hines-Allen and Moore – only the third and fourth McDonald's All Americans to sign with U of L – were signature recruits for Walz, and they're living up to the hype. They've started every game and helped fill the scoring void left by last year's seniors Shoni Schimmel, Asia Taylor, Antonita Slaughter and Tia Gibbs.

"I thought I would come in and work hard and try to make a starting position or try to be a factor, but I never knew that (it would happen)," Moore said. "I was like, 'This isn't too bad.' I stressed a lot about how hard college games would be at the Division I level – and don't get me wrong, it is – but I just had a different idea of what it would be."

A freshman hasn't led U of L in scoring since Gwen Doyle averaged 17.9 points in 1990-91, but that could change. In comparison to a few recent greats, Hines-Allen's 15.1-point average is tied with Shoni Schimmel's freshman average in 2010-11, and both she and Moore are well ahead of the freshman average of Angel McCoughtry (9.2) in 2005-06.

Hines-Allen, coming off a career-high 21 points against Valparaiso on Sunday, has scored in double figures in every game, the longest streak to start a U of L career since Jazz Covington did it 14 straight times in 2003-04. A key finisher in the paint, she is tops on the team in field-goal percentage (.642) and tied for third in rebounding (4.6 per game).

Walz called Hines-Allen "a natural scorer" with "the ability to score at will," and he's not been that surprised to see her and Moore lead the team in points.

"I think I've done a lot better than I expected," Hines-Allen said. "…I just decided just to come in and give it my all, and then let the coaches decide whether I could have a starting position here. I just came in and worked hard every day to prove to my teammates and the coaches that I deserve to be on the floor."

Mariya Moore said things are going well as she adjusts to college.

Hines-Allen and Moore are pleased with their start but know things will get tougher. U of L has yet to play a team from one of the five power conferences and is winning by 31 points per game. Thursday night, U of L will make its debut in the ACC/Big Ten Challenge against an Iowa squad that U of L ripped 83-53 on the road in the second round of last season's NCAA Tournament. Walz is expecting the Hawkeyes to come to the KFC Yum! Center fired up and looking for payback.

And Hines-Allen and Moore are ready to see how they respond to the step up in competition.

"The season is starting to really pick up now, so the real challenge is coming," said Moore, who has scored 22 points twice this season. "So I have to see how I adjust to better teams that we play."

Moore's 3-point shooting has been, as Walz said, "a pleasant surprise" for a team that lost long-range bombers Schimmel, Slaughter and Gibbs. She's made a team-high 11 threes this season, including a 6-of-9 performance against Ball State.

Moore is also second on the team in assists (29), with only eight turnovers – a "fantastic" ratio, Walz said.

"Some people just try to get theirs, but Mariya is not the selfish type," Hines-Allen said. "She looks to make the extra pass on the fast break. And that extra pass is going to be a nice pass."

So how can these freshmen improve?

Moore said she needs to build skill and confidence in using her left hand.

Hines-Allen said she's working hard to get better defense.

"They're both willing to learn, and that's what is really going to separate them from a lot of talented kids," Walz said. "They're willing to accept criticism, willing to accept coaching, and they want to be the best."

Steve Jones can be reached at (502) 582-7176 and followed on Twitter at @SteveJones_CJ.

UP NEXT

IOWA AT LOUISVILLE

7 p.m. Thursday, ESPN3
